body.p:
darktable comes with a number of settings that can be configured by users. You reach the configuration menu by clicking
at the top of the screen.
These options control the look and feel of darktable.

p.b: interface language

body.p: set the language of the user interface. the system default is marked with an * (needs a restart)

p.b: theme

body.p: set the theme for the user interface

p.b: ignore JPEG images when importing film rolls

body.p: When having RAW+JPEG images together in one directory it makes no sense to import both. With this flag one can ignore all JPEGs found (default off).

p.b: recursive directory traversal when importing film rolls

body.p: Not only import images from the directory selected but recursively go through all subdirectories as well (default off).

p.b: creator to be applied when importing

body.p: If provided, automatically add this string as a creator tag when importing images (default none).

p.b: publisher to be applied when importing

body.p: If provided, automatically add this string as a publisher tag when importing images (default none).

p.b: rights to be applied when importing

body.p: If provided, automatically add this string as a copyrights tag when importing images (default none).

p.b: comma separated tags to be applied when importing

body.p: If you want to add further tags when importing images, you can give them as a comma separated list (default none).

p.b: initial import rating

body.p: Initial star rating (from 0 to 5) for all images when importing a film roll (default 1).

p.b: don't use embedded preview JPEG but half-size raw

body.p: Check this option to not use the embedded JPEG from the raw file but process the raw data. This is slower. (default off).

p.b: high quality thumb processing from size

body.p: If the thumbnails size is greater than this value, it will be processed using the full quality rendering path which is better but slower (default 720p).

p.b: enable extended thumb overlay

body.p: If enabled adds additional information to the thumbnail under the mouse cursor: image name, exposure time, aperture, focal length, ISO value (default off).

p.b: use single-click in the collect panel

body.p: (default off). In single-click mode, you can select range of value directly with the mouse.

p.b: expand a single lighttable module at a time

body.p: Controls how lighttable panels are expanded. If this option is enabled, expanding a panel by clicking collapses any currently expanded panel. If you want to expand a panel without collapsing the others you do so with Shift+click. Disabling this option reverts the meaning of click and Shift+click (default off).

p.b: scroll to lighttable modules when expanded/collapsed

body.p: With this option enabled the lighttable side panels will scroll a module to the top when it is expanded or collapsed (default off).

p.b: rating an image one star twice will not zero out the rating

body.p: Normally clicking a one star rating twice will set a zero star rating to that image. When checking this option a second click on a one star rating will keep that rating (default off).

p.b: pen pressure control for brush masks

body.p: Controls how the pressure reading of a graphics tablet impacts newly generated brush strokes (see ). You can control the brush width, its hardness and its opacity. Absolute control means that the pressure reading directly defines the attribute with a value between 0% and 100%. Relative means that the pressure reading adjusts the attribute between zero and the pre-defined default value (default off).

p.b: smoothing of brush strokes

body.p: Sets the level for smoothing of brush strokes. Stronger smoothing leads to less nodes and easier editing at the expense of lower accuracy.

p.b: display of individual color channels

body.p: Controls how individual color channels are displayed when activated in the parametric masks feature. You can choose between false color and grey scale (default false color).

p.b: pattern for the image infos line

body.p: See for available values.

p.b: position of the image info line

body.p: Controls in which panel we display the image info line. You can choose between top left top right top center bottom and hidden (default bottom).

p.b: show search module text entry

body.p: Controls how to determine which modules are shown at the same time in the right panel. You can choose between groups icons search entry both (default both). (need a restart)

p.b: expand a single darkroom module at a time

body.p: Controls how darkroom modules are expanded. If this option is enabled, expanding a module by clicking collapses any currently expanded module. If you want to expand a module without collapsing the others you do so with Shift+click. Disabling this option reverts the meaning of click and Shift+click (default on).

p.b: expand the module when it is activated, and collapse it when disabled

body.p: This option allows to expand or collapse automatically modules when they are enabled or disabled. (default off)

p.b: scroll to darkroom modules when expanded/collapsed

body.p: With this option enabled the darkroom side panel will scroll a module to the top when it is expanded or collapsed (default on).

p.b: border around image in darkroom mode

body.p: Process the image in darkroom mode with a small border of the given number of pixels (default 20).

p.b: only draw images on map that are currently collected and filtered

body.p: Use the current filter settings to select the geotagged images drawn in the map view. This limits the images drawn to those currently shown in the filmstrip and thus reduces the time needed (default off).

p.b: maximum number of images drawn on map

body.p: The maximum number of geotagged images drawn on the map. Increasing this number can slow down the drawing of the map. Needs a restart if changed (default 100).

p.b: pretty print the image location

body.p: Show a more readable representation of the geo location in the image information module (default on).

p.b: ask before removing images from database

body.p: Always ask the user before any image is removed from the database (default on).

p.b: ask before erasing images from disk

body.p: Always ask the user before any image file is deleted (default on).

p.b: send files to trash when erasing images

body.p: Instead of physically deleting images from disk put them into the system's trash bin (default on).

p.b: ask before moving images from film roll folder

body.p: Always ask the user before any image file is moved (default on).

p.b: ask before copying images to new film roll folder

body.p: Always ask the user before any image file is copied (default on).

p.b: ask before removing empty folders

body.p: Always ask the user before removing any empty folder. This can happen after moving or deleting images (default off).

p.b: ask before deleting a tag

body.p: Always ask user before deleting a tag from an image (default on).

p.b: ask before deleting a style

body.p: Always ask user before deleting a style (default on).

p.b: width of the side panels in pixels

body.p: This controls the size of side panels in pixels. Side panels are found left and right to the center view (default 350).

p.b: waiting time before each picture in slideshow

body.p: The number of seconds before displaying the next image (default 5).

p.b: do not show april 1st game

body.p: (default on).

p.b: number of folder levels to show in lists

body.p: The number of folder levels to show in film roll names, starting from the right (default 1).

p.b: enable filmstrip

body.p: Enable the filmstrip in darkroom, tethering, geomapping and lighttable culling modes (default on).

p.b: enable timeline

body.p: Enable the timeline lighttable mode (default on).

p.b: overlay txt sidecar over zoomed images

body.p: When there is a text file next to an image it can be shown as an overlay over zoomed images on the lighttable. The text file has the same base name as the image file with file extension .txt. It either has to be there at import time or the crawler has to be enabled – see option look for updated xmp files on startup in (default off).

p.b: mouse wheel scrolls modules side panel by default

body.p: When enabled, mouse wheel scroll modules side panel, and Ctrl+Alt+mouse wheel scroll data entry. When disabled, this behavior is reversed (default off).

p.b: show scrollbars for center view

body.p: Defines in which modes scrollbars should be displayed (default lighttable).

p.b: always show panels scrollbars

body.p: Defines whether the panel scrollbars should be always visible or activated only depending on the content (default on). (need a restart)

p.b: method to use for getting the display profile

body.p: This option allows to force a specific way of getting the current display profile for color management (see ). In the default setting all darktable will either query the X display server's xatom or the colord system service. You can set this option to xatom or colord to enforce a specific method if the alternative gives wrong results.
These options control some of the internals of darktable.

p.b: color manage cached thumbnails

body.p: If activated darktable generates thumbnails in a general color space (AdobeRGB) in order to render them independently of the individual monitor. Conversion to the monitor color space is done at display time. If this option is not activated thumbnails are directly stored in the specific monitor color space valid at generation time and are subsequently displayed without further corrections (default on).

p.b: always use LittleCMS 2 to apply output color profile

body.p: If this option is activated, darktable will use system library LittleCMS 2 instead of its own routines. This is significantly slower than the default but might give more accurate results in some cases (default off).
Note that if the given ICC is LUT-based or contains both, a LUT and a matrix, darktable will use LittleCMS 2 to render the colors regardless of this configuration parameter's value.

p.b: do high quality processing for slideshow

body.p: Controls how images are processed for the slideshow view. It this option is enabled, the image will first be processed in full resolution, and downscaled at the very end. This can result in better quality sometimes, but will always be slower (default on).

p.b: demosaicing for zoomed out darkroom mode

body.p: Interpolation when not viewing 1:1 in darkroom mode: always bilinear (fast) is fastest, but not as sharp. at most ppg (reasonable) is using ppg + interpolation modes specified below, full (possibly slow) will use exactly the settings for full-size export (default at most ppg (reasonable)).

p.b: pixel interpolator

body.p: Pixel interpolator used in rotation, lens correction, up-and-down scaling; options are bilinear, bicubic, lanczos2, lanczos3 (default).

p.b: auto-apply basecurve

body.p: Use a basecurve by default. For more details see (default on). (need a restart)

p.b: auto-apply per camera basecurve presets

body.p: Use the per-camera basecurve by default instead of the generic manufacturer one if there is one available. For more details see (default off).

p.b: auto-apply sharpen

body.p: This added sharpen is not recommended on cameras without a low-pass filter. The default is to not add any sharpening automatically as most recent cameras have no low-pass filter. (need a restart)

p.b: write sidecar file for each image

body.p: These redundant XMP files can later be re-imported into a different database, preserving your changes to the image. It's strongly recommended to have this option activated so you don't lose data in case of a database corruption. Backing up your raw file plus the accompanying XMP file will allow you to fully restore your work (default on).

p.b: store xmp tags in compressed format

body.p: Entries in XMP tags can get rather large and may exceed the available space to store the history stack in output files on export. This option allows binary XMP tags to be compressed in order to save space. Available options are never, always, and only large entries (default).

p.b: look for updated xmp files on startup

body.p: Check file modification times of all XMP files on startup to find out if any got updated in the meantime by some other software. If updated XMP files are found a menu opens for the user to decide which of the XMP files to be reloaded – replacing darktable's database entries by the XMP file contents – and which of the XMP files to be overwritten by darktable's database. Activating this option also causes darktable to check for text sidecar files that have been added after import time – see option overlay txt sidecar over zoomed images in (default off).

p.b: memory in megabytes to use for thumbnail cache

body.p: In order to speed-up display of film rolls, darktable stores thumbnails in a cache file on disk (primary cache) and loads it into memory at startup. This value controls the cache size in megabytes. It needs a restart if changed (default 256MB).

p.b: enable disk backend for thumbnail cache

body.p: If activated darktable stores all thumbnails on disk as a secondary cache, and thereby keeping thumbnails accessible in case they get dropped from the primary cache. This needs more disk space but speeds up lighttable view as it avoids reprocessing of thumbnails (default on).

p.b: enable disk backend for full preview cache

body.p: If enabled, darktable write full preview to disk (.cache/darktable/) when evicted from the memory cache. Note that this can take a lot of memory (several gigabytes for 20k images) and darktable will never delete cached images. It's safe though to delete these manually, if you want. Lighttable performance will be increased greatly when zooming image in full preview mode (default off).

p.b: number of background threads

body.p: This controls how many parallel threads are used to create thumbnails during import. On 32bit systems it is strongly recommended to set this to 1. Needs a restart if changed (default 2).

p.b: host memory limit (in MB) for tiling

body.p: In order to manage large images on systems with limited memory darktable does tile-wise processing. This variable controls the maximum amount of memory (in MB) a module may use during image processing. Lower values will force memory hungry modules to process an image with increasing number of tiles. Setting this to 0 will omit any limits. Values below 500 will be treated as 500. On a 32bit system you should set this to 500. Needs a restart if changed (default 1500).

p.b: minimum amount of memory (in MB) for a single buffer in tiling

body.p: If set to a positive, non-zero value, this variable defines the minimum amount of memory (in MB) that darktable should take for a single tile. On a 32bit system you should set this to 8. 64bit systems can live with higher values. Needs a restart if changed (default 16).

p.b: activate OpenCL support

body.p: darktable can use your GPU to speed up processing significantly. Interface OpenCL requires suitable hardware and matching OpenCL drivers on your system. If one of those is not found the option is greyed out. Can be switched on and off at any time and takes immediate effect (default on).

p.b: OpenCL scheduling profile

body.p: Defines how preview and full pixelpipe tasks are scheduled on OpenCL enabled systems. default: the GPU processes the center view pixelpipe and the CPU processes the preview pipe; multiple GPUs: both pixelpipes are processed in parallel on two different GPUs; very fast GPU: both pixelpipes are processed sequentially on the GPU.

p.b: omit hierarchy in simple tag lists

body.p: When exporting images the hierarchical tags are also added as a simple list of non-hierarchical ones to make them visible to some other programs. When this option is checked darktable will only include their last part and ignore the rest. So foo|bar|baz will only add baz.

p.b: force exportation of private tags

body.p: This option force darktable to export private tags to XMP-dc Subject and XMP-lr Hierarchical Subject (default off).

p.b: request exportation of synonyms

body.p: This option force darktable to export synonyms along with tags to XMP-dc Subject (default off).

p.b: disable the entry completion

body.p: The entry completion is useful for those who enter tags from keyboard only. For others the entry completion can be embarrassing (default off). (need a restart)

p.b: password storage backend to use

body.p: The storage backend for password storage. Options: auto (default), none, libsecret, kwallet.

p.b: executable for playing audio files

body.p: Defines an external program which is used in the lighttable view to play audio files that some cameras record to keep notes for images (default aplay).

p.b: 3D lut root folder

body.p: This folder (and sub-folders) contains Lut files used by lut3d modules. (need a restart)
These options define a naming pattern to organize images on disk when importing from a connected camera (see ) and when taking photos in the tethering view (see ).

The naming pattern consists of three parts: a base part defining the parent folder, a session part defining a sub directory which is specific to the individual import session, and a file name part defining the filename structure for each imported image.
Several pre-defined variables can be used in the pattern as placeholders:

row.entry: the home folder as defined by the system
the pictures folder as defined by the system (usually $HOME/Pictures)
the desktop folder as defined by the system (usually $HOME/Desktop)
your user account name on the system
unique identifier of the import job
a sequence number within the import job
maximum image width to limit within export session
maximum image height to limit within export session
unique identification number of the image in darktable's database
year at the date of import
month at the date of import
day at the date of import
hour at the time of import
minute at the time of import
second at the time of import
year the photo was taken (from Exif data)
month the photo was taken (from Exif data)
day the photo was taken (from Exif data)
hour the photo was taken (from Exif data)
minute the photo was taken (from Exif data)
seconds the photo was taken (from Exif data)
ISO value of the photo (from Exif data)

p.b: base directory naming pattern

body.p: The base directory part of the naming pattern (default $(PICTURES_FOLDER)/Darktable).

p.b: sub directory naming pattern

body.p: The sub directory part of the naming pattern (default $(YEAR)$(MONTH)$(DAY)_$(JOBCODE)).

p.b: file naming pattern

body.p: The file name part of the naming pattern (default $(YEAR)$(MONTH)$(DAY)_$(SEQUENCE).$(FILE_EXTENSION).
darktable has a large set of keyboard shortcuts that is user configurable through the preference dialog.

When you open the shortcuts menu you are presented with a hierarchical list of all actions that can receive a keyboard shortcut. Go to the action you want to change and double click. You are then prompted to press the new key combination to be mapped to the selected action. In order to remove an existing keyboard shortcut, click on the action and press backspace.
In addition to classic shortcuts, you can set dynamic shortcuts to some darkroom module sliders. This allow you to change the value of the mapped slider with key + mouse scroll.
You can export your mappings to a file or import mappings from a file. Press default to reset all keyaccelerators to their default state.

This menu gives you an overview of the presets that are defined for darktable's modules. In this dialog you can select whether a certain user defined preset shall be auto-applied to matching images. By pressing the import button at the bottom of the window you can import a saved preset.
Pre-defined presets are shown with a lock symbol. Their auto-apply properties can not be changed.
Double clicking on a user-defined preset will open a menu. This allows editing the preset or saving it to an external .dtpreset file.

p.b: auto apply this preset to matching images

body.p: activate this checkbutton to automatically apply the preset on newly imported images; a set of fields is displayed where you can define patterns to be matched against Exif data.

p.b: only show this preset for matching images

body.p: activate this checkbutton to hide the preset in darkroom mode if it does not match the defined patterns.

p.b: model

body.p: a pattern to be matched against the Exif field that describes your camera model; use "%" as wildcard.

p.b: maker

body.p: a pattern to be matched against the Exif field that describes the maker of your camera; use "%" as wildcard.

p.b: lens

body.p: a pattern to be matched against the Exif field that describes your lens; use "%" as wildcard.

p.b: iso

body.p: only apply the preset if the ISO value of your image lies within the given range.

p.b: exposure

body.p: only apply the preset if the exposure time of your image lies within the given range; set "+" as the upper value to match arbitrarily long exposures.

p.b: aperture

body.p: only apply the preset if the aperture of your image lies within the given range; set "f/0" as the lower value to match arbitrarily open apertures; set "f/+" as the upper value to match arbitrarily closed apertures.

p.b: focal length

body.p: only apply the preset if the focal length of your image lies within the given range (from 0 to 1000).
